title: Who Do You Think You Are (Candlewick Green song)
text:
"Who Do You Think You Are" is a song written by the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> <a href="Songwriter">songwriting-team</a> Des Dyer and <a href="Clive%20Scott">Clive Scott</a>. The song was first recorded by the <a href="pop%20music">pop</a> <a href="musical%20ensemble">group</a> <a href="Candlewick%20Green">Candlewick Green</a> and released in late December 1973. The song peaked at #21 in the United Kingdom in February 1974.
Bo Donaldson and the Heywoods version.
<a href="Bo%20Donaldson%20and%20the%20Heywoods">Bo Donaldson and the Heywoods</a> covered "Who Do You Think You Are" in 1974. Their version became a hit in both the United States and Canada. It peaked at #15 on the U.S. "Billboard" <a href="Hot%20100">Hot 100</a> and #13 on "Cash Box". It was a bigger hit in Canada, where it reached #11. It was also an Adult Contemporary hit in both nations.
Saint Etienne version.
The British <a href="alternative%20dance">indie dance</a>/<a href="indie%20pop">indie pop</a> band <a href="Saint%20Etienne%20%28band%29">Saint Etienne</a> released an <a href="alternative%20dance">alternative dance</a>-pop arrangement of "Who Do You Think You Are" in 1993. This version featured Debsey Wykes as co-lead vocalist, sometime backing singing for the band and former singer of <a href="Dolly%20Mixture">Dolly Mixture</a>. It peaked at number 23 on the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a> as a double A-side with "<a href="Hobart%20Paving">Hobart Paving</a>").
Critical reception.
Stewart Mason from <a href="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> stated that "Who Do You Think You Are" is "one of St. Etienne's most groove-oriented tunes." <a href="Larry%20Flick">Larry Flick</a> from "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" wrote, "English modern-pop act delves into <a href="Bo%20Donaldson%20and%20the%20Heywoods">Bo Donaldson & the Heywoods</a>' pop evergreen with fanciful, <a href="disco">disco</a>-minded results. Singer Debsey offers a soft, sugar-coated vocal with a pleasant, cushiony <a href="house%20music">house</a> groove resting beneath." He added, "Far more interesting and effective than the group's previous releases." Music writer <a href="James%20Masterton">James Masterton</a> said in his weekly UK chart commentary, that it is "a completely new track, a superbly crafted bit of pop which should be Top 10 if there is any justice in the world. We shall see."
Music video.
A <a href="music%20video">music video</a> was produced to promote the single. It was published on <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> in May 2012.
Track listings.
All tracks written and composed by Dyer and <a href="Clive%20Scott">Scott</a>; except where indicated.
